Key Arguments: The bill is seen as an overreach of government power, potentially leading to censorship and a chilling effect on free speech.
The definitions of 'misinformation' and 'disinformation' are considered overly broad and unworkable.
The bill could create a double standard where government-approved information is not considered misinformation, disadvantaging critics of the government.
The bill's coercive powers and record-keeping requirements are seen as excessive and potentially harmful to privacy.
The bill is perceived as insufficiently protective of freedom of expression and privacy interests.
Notable Quotes: To put a government department in charge of what is ‘information’ and what is not is to take a huge leap towards fascism.
The Bill’s interference with the self-fulfilment of free expression will occur primarily by the chilling self-censorship it will inevitably bring about.
The statutory definition of ‘misinformation’ is over-broad and unworkable.
The Bill creates an unlevel playing field between governments and other speakers.
